chapter1.description: Doubts are setting in. A choice must be made

text.speaker: Director
text: Hello, everyone. Welcome to the University of Orleans, a place where imagination meets logic and where every bug is an opportunity for creativity.
This year, as every year, we will explore fascinating areas: from artificial intelligence to distributed systems, from web development to quantum architectures that are still somewhat mysterious.
But beyond languages and frameworks, what we seek to impart to you is critical thinking, curiosity, and the ability to solve problems... even those that seem impossible at first glance. Thank you.

text.speaker: Professor
text.text: I am your formal calculation professor, Antoine Robert. I used to be just like you: a student at this university, sitting in the same seats as you. By listening to lectures and working hard, I managed to get this teaching position. I am now a research professor, which involves...

The protagonist keeps listening to his teacher.

text: - ... teaching in schools while conducting research the rest of the time. Now that you know about my background, I will discuss the content of my course.
We will have a final exam at the end of the semester and about ten tutorials and practical classes to prepare for it. Each class will be divided into two parts -...

[I wait for the end of the day with a knot in my stomach. It takes me several hours to fully realize what is happening.]

text: [Rejected... I thought it would be a shock... but actually, it's more of a strange mix of feelings. Surprise... and at the same time, not really. In high school, I was good. Really good. Everyone told me I had potential, that I was “cut out for studying.” Yet I completely dropped out.]

[The truth is... I wasn't interested. I tried to convince myself otherwise, I followed the path everyone expected of me, but every class seemed... empty. Far from what I really wanted to do. And of course, because I wasn't motivated... I didn't give it my all. I did the bare minimum, sometimes nothing at all. How could I have succeeded like that? It wasn't for me. And I only realize that now, too late.]

What do I want to do? What really motivates me? Continuing down a path that doesn't suit me will only lead to more failures. Well... I need to find something that suits me. And this time... I need to really commit to it.
[I spent the night researching. With Parcoursup closing several weeks ago, it will be very difficult for me to find a program that will accept me.]

[Why didn't I realize I was heading straight for disaster earlier this year? I'm forced to turn to subjects that rarely fill up classes and accept any grades, such as literature or history. I'm far from my ideal, but you never know! Maybe I'm actually cut out for this kind of study. It's totally different from computer science, after all!]

I… I didn't invest enough in my studies. I had trouble getting interested in what I was doing and… I didn't give my best.

text.speaker: Moi
text: Hello, my parents gave me your number so that I could ask you some questions.
I am currently considering a career change and they think you could advise me
Please let me know when you are available.

text.speaker: Lucas
text.text: Hello, I would be happy to help you. I am available right now.

text.speaker: Moi
text.text: Thank you very much ! First I would like to know what you were studying at the beginning.

text.speaker: Lucas
text: When I left secondary school in 2015, I enrolled in a preparatory class for the grandes écoles littéraires, a CPGE,
with the aim of preparing for the competitive entrance exam to become a teacher of classical literature
as this was what I had wanted to do since my second year of secondary school.

text.speaker: Moi
text.text: When did you stop enjoying your studies ?

text.speaker: Lucas
text: I quickly realised that this preparatory class was not for me. In December, I realised this very quickly because the teachers were certainly very demanding, but that was a good thing.
Above all, they made us understand that we were there to prepare for the political science entrance exam. And that was something that didn't interest me at all.

I had to deal with a lot of disappointment from the teachers in this preparatory class, which led me to reflect and reorient myself in order to really put all the odds in my favour and prepare for the CAPES, the competitive exam for the national education system.

text.speaker: Moi
text.text: What made you hesitate ?

text.speaker: Lucas
text: What made me hesitate at first was what my parents and those around me were saying, that it was still a preparatory class for the grandes écoles and that it was still preparing me for a competitive exam, so if it prepared me for the political science exam, it could also prepare me for the exam to become a teacher.

It's true that at first it made me hesitate a little. But I was told that it would be beneficial. It would teach me methodology and rigour in terms of the quantity of work, the quality of work, everything related to personal work, etc.
That it would be very positive for the teaching entrance exam later on. And that I had to take advantage of this preparatory class.

text.speaker: Moi
text.text: What made you decide it was time to make a change ?

text.speaker: Lucas
text: I decided to follow the advice of those around me and finish this first year of preparatory classes. However, at the end of the first year, I asked to change direction because I didn't feel like doing a second year under those conditions.

Because, basically, I wanted to take the teaching exam to become a teacher of classical literature. During that preparatory year, I also had a teacher of classical literature who was really demoralising.
Very demotivating. In everything he made us do. He put us down a lot, which ended up making me a little tired of the subject and made me realise that it wasn't what I wanted to do.
So, I decided to change direction this time to my second choice, which was still in the national education system, but this time as a Spanish teacher.

I was able to go straight into the second year and from there I began to study Spanish history, Spanish language, Spanish literature, etc. and so I began to prepare for my competitive examination to become a Spanish teacher.

text.speaker: Moi
text.text: Were you worried about what others would say ?

text.speaker: Lucas
text.text: I wasn't afraid at all to change direction because of how others might perceive me. What I do, I do for myself, I don't do it for others.

text.speaker: Moi
text.text: How did you find the change of direction ? Did it make you feel more relived or stressed ?

text.speaker: Lucas
text: I really felt relieved by this change of direction, because from that moment on, I was truly able to focus on what I wanted to do and not on what I was tired of,
since those were really the two choices I was hesitating between. So, I really saw this change of direction to study Spanish at university as a new opportunity.
I wasn't stressed at all. On the contrary, I saw it as a kind of liberation, finally being able to do what I loved and flourish in what I was doing.

text.speaker: Moi
text.text: Did you receive any support from anyone ?

text.speaker: Lucas
text: I really had a lot of support around me, my whole family encouraged me, as did my acquaintances, my friends, and my secondary school teachers.

They also encouraged me by telling me that if this was really what I wanted, I had to go for it, and that if it was the best thing for me, university would prepare me just as well as the preparatory class.

text.speaker: Moi
text.text: Did you notice a big difference compared to your previous school ?

text.speaker: Lucas
text: When I arrived at university, I really felt a big difference compared to prep school, because there, we were much more independent, much freer. In preparatory classes, we had teachers who were very supportive and demanded a lot from us, which forced us to be consistent and work hard.

So when I arrived at university, having much more autonomy than in preparatory classes helped me. I had acquired during my first year of preparatory classes, I had acquired a great deal of rigour in terms of work, in terms of quality, in terms of seriousness, so when I arrived at university it was really much more relaxed,

I was much better organised, I was much more studious, the pace with the preparatory classes was therefore very different in terms of atmosphere as well, since in preparatory classes we were still a class of about thirty, whereas when I arrived at university, there were 12 of us in my year, so being in a really
small group was great, we could help each other more easily, etc. It was a totally different pace and a totally different atmosphere that I enjoyed much more and found easier to thrive in easier

text.speaker: Moi
text.text: What about the administrative side ?

text.speaker: Lucas
text: On the administrative side, no hassle. The change of direction went extremely well.
The fact that I waited until the end of the preparatory year to change direction meant that it happened naturally, as we had two choices to make.
Either we wanted to continue into the second year of the preparatory course, or we wanted to go straight into the second year of a bachelor's degree.

text.speaker: Moi
text.text: Would you make the same choices if you could go back in time ?

text.speaker: Lucas
text: If I could go back today, I would definitely make the same choices because I flourished in what I was doing.
And that's very important when you're studying, to flourish in what you want to do, because that's what shapes your future career.

text.speaker: Moi
text.text: Thank you very much for your reply! It will help me make up mind. Have a nice day.

text.speaker: Lucas
text.text: No problem, I'm glad I could help. Have a nice day.
[He helped me a lot, I feel better and more confident in my decision to change my academic path.]
